title: Sample Size, Identifiability and MCMC Efficiency in Complex Random Effect Models
abstractText:
Random effect modelling is now widely accepted in social, health and other research areas as a tool for the analysis of complex data structures. This project considers three related research issues that need addressing to support and strengthen existing research on complex random effect models.

Sample size calculation involves estimating how much data should be collected to answer particular quantitative research questions. Here we will aim to consider such calculations when the underlying data structure is complicated by dependencies within the data. We will consider a simulation-based strategy where many datasets similar to that which the user intends collecting are generated. These simulated datasets are then used to decide the appropriateness of particular sample sizes.

Such a simulation-based approach is computationally intensive and involves fitting a statistical model to each simulated dataset. It is therefore paramount to use efficient estimation algorithms in the fitting stage of our approach. We will often need to use a family of estimation methods called MCMC methods to fit our models. This section of our project therefore investigates and supplements existing research on efficient MCMC algorithms for complex random effect models.

Finally the project considers the issue of model identifiability. This assesses whether the structure of a dataset will actually allow particular models to be fitted.
